response:
Subacute onset over about 10 days with persistence over weeks and a purely cerebellar syndrome in a 61-year-old man raises concern for a structural lesion of the right cerebellar hemisphere. Vascular causes (infarct, less likely haemorrhage) are common and can present subacutely. Tumours (primary or metastatic) and demyelination can also cause a focal cerebellar syndrome of this tempo. Immune/paraneoplastic cerebellitis and toxic-metabolic causes are broader considerations but are less consistent with the strictly unilateral, focal findings.
